sols_html:
As suggested in the hint, we will simplify the limit on the left hand side of the equal sign. If we just plug in 2 we get 0/0, so we will have to do some simplifying. Because the numerator and denominator are polynomials, factoring is a good first step.

The denominator is a difference of squares, so we can write:

\(\lim_{x \to 2} \frac{x-2}{4-x^2} = \lim_{x \to 2}\frac{2-x}{(2-x)(2+x)}\)

Canceling the common terms, and then plugging in the 2 gives:

\(\lim_{x \to 2}\frac{1}{2 + x} = \frac{1}{2 + 2} = \frac14\)

Which matches the right hand side of the original equation. Thus the statement is true.
